title: Reform of the International Monetary System and Internationalization of the Renminbi Sustainability of the Current International Monetary System 73 of the President, the U.S. personal savings ratio dropped to –1% in 2006, the lowest since World War II.6 Meanwhile, the U.S

fund wars, thus causing persistent fiscal deficits. In most years since 1980, the U.S. government savings have been in the negative, seriously affecting the U.S. gross national savings.7 The United States, as a result, has to attract foreign capital to fill in the domestic investment gap, thus creating a trade deficit. Figure 7-3 shows that the U.S. trade deficit as a share of GDP and its savings investment gap as a share of GDP followed similar trends over those years. This shows that U.S. trade deficit is the external manifestation of imbalance between internal savings and investment, a natural outcome of inadequate national savings
Europe and Japan mostly had current account surpluses
however, emerging Asian economies represented by China and oil-producing countries have acquired a major share of the global current account surplus

title: The 2008 financial crisis originated in the U.S. residential housing mortgage market. As the crisis spread and escalated, the U.S. real estate bubble got squeezed. In late May, 2009, the S&P/Case–Shiller Home Price Indices of 20 U.S. cities dropped to 139.84 points, one-third below its peak of 206.52 points in July 2006, and the drop exceeded 50% in some regions

title: In the second quarter of 2009, the average U.S. home price is basically at the same level as that at the end of 2002 (Figure 9-2).1 A rebound in the U.S. real estate market depends on increased effective demand. But at a time of persistent recession, sluggish real economy and increasing unemployment, the U.S. real estate market will remain bearish for some time to come
